content: The Act titled "DNA Sexual Assault Justice Act of 2002" requires an assessment of the backlog in DNA analysis of samples. The Attorney General will survey law enforcement jurisdictions to assess the backlog of DNA testing of rape kit samples and other sexual assault evidence. This includes determining the amount of evidence in rape kits and from sexual assault crimes that has not been subjected to DNA testing and analysis. A report must be submitted within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress on the assessment of DNA testing backlog in rape kit samples and sexual assault evidence. The report will include the results of the assessment, the number of untested samples, and a plan for ongoing assessments until all jurisdictions have no backlog. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. "Amendments to the DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 include grants for analysis of DNA samples from rape kits and nonsuspect cases to ensure timely testing. Increased grants for DNA analysis are also provided." The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to increase grants for DNA analysis, with specific funding allocations for fiscal years 2003 to 2006. Local governments have the authority to apply for and receive DNA backlog elimination grants. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include eligible units of local government in the grant application process. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include eligible units of local government in the grant application process by making specific changes to subsections (E) and (F) regarding certification requirements. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include eligible units of local government in the grant application process by making specific changes to subsections regarding certification requirements. The amendments involve inserting "or unit of local government" after "State" in various subsections. SEC. 6. IMPROVING ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR BACKLOG GRANTS. Section 2 of the DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to ensure that laboratories meet quality assurance protocols for DNA testing. Priority in grant awards will be given to states with significant rape kit or nonsuspect case backlogs. AUTHORIZATION FOR GRANTS FOR IMPROVED RESPONSES TO AND INVESTIGATION OF SEXUAL ASSAULT CASES. The Attorney General authorizes grants to eligible entities for sexual assault examiner training, program development, forensic equipment acquisition, law enforcement personnel training, and recognition of drug-facilitated sexual assaults. Eligible entities include states, local governments, universities, and sexual assault examination programs. Authorization of Appropriations: Funds under this section are not to replace State funds but to increase the total amount available. Administrative costs are limited to 3% of received funds. Eligible entities can still seek Federal funding from other sources. $15,000,000 is authorized for the Department of Justice annually. The Department of Justice is authorized $15,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2003 through 2006 to carry out this section. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZING JOHN DOE DNA INDICTMENTS. Section 3282 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new provision for DNA Profile Indictments in cases where the identity of the accused is unknown. Indictments found within 5 years after the offense under chapter 109A are not subject to the limitations period described in subsection (a) or the provisions of chapter 208. The amendment to Section 3282 of title 18, United States Code allows for DNA Profile Indictments in cases where the defendant's identity is unknown. Indictments found within 5 years after the offense under chapter 109A are not subject to the limitations period described in subsection (a) or the provisions of chapter 208. Additionally, Rule 7 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to provide guidelines for describing unknown defendants in such cases. The amendment to Section 3282 of title 18, US Code allows for DNA Profile Indictments in cases where the defendant's identity is unknown, describing the defendant in the indictment as an individual with a particular DNA profile. SEC. 9 amends the DNA Identification Act of 1994 to authorize $9,646,000 for the redesign of the Combined DNA Index System (CODIS) in fiscal year 2003. SEC. 10 authorizes $497,000 for the Federal Convicted Offender Program (FCOP) in fiscal year 2003.
